;;周三官方数据显示，英国8月份年度消费者价格通胀意外降至6.7%，而前一天英国央行预计将再次加息。弗朗西斯·马奎尔报道。;
;;
;< Small style="color: #999;">;2022 年 6 月 27 日，英国伦敦西部里士满，一名员工在 Sainsbury's 超市内摆放农产品。照片摄于 2022 年 6 月 27 日。REUTERS/Henry Nicholls;
;

;英国高通胀率意外放缓，增加了英国央行最快周四暂停长期加息的可能性。

;

;英镑下跌，投资者看到近50-50在 8 月份消费者价格指数跌至 18 个月低点 6.7% 后，英国央行 9 月份会议上维持利率不变的可能性。

;

;这仅比 7 月份的 6.8% 略有下降，但在面对路透社和英国央行调查的经济学家对加息的预测。

;

;潜在的通胀指标更加急剧减弱，这开启了英国央行行长安德鲁·贝利及其货币政策委员会 (MPC) 的可能性自 2021 年 12 月以来连续 14 次加息后，同事们将于周四维持利率不变。

;

;经济学家 Chris Hare 表示，“核心通胀的大幅下行意外给英格兰银行带来了重大的曲线球”

;

;最近数据中的强劲工资增长意味着加息仍然是周四最有可能的结果，但“今天的数据增加了货币政策委员会将继续按兵不动的风险，”他说。< /p>;

;英镑兑美元汇率下跌0.5美分，至5月份以来的最低水平，兑欧元汇率也下跌

;

;通胀放缓是由经常波动的酒店价格下跌推动的国家统计局表示，这抵消了全球燃油价格上涨和酒精饮料税增加的影响。

;

; >;

;英国的通胀率已从去年 10 月 11% 以上的峰值回落，但即使在最近一次下降之后，英国的通胀率仍然位居西欧最高之列，8 月份仅次于奥地利和冰岛。

;

;但核心通胀（剔除波动较大的食品和能源价格）从 7 月份的 6.9% 大幅下降至 6.2%。

;

;同样受到英国央行密切关注的服务业通胀也失去了部分动力，放缓至 6.8 % 从 7.4% 上升。

;

;“周四的英格兰银行会议变得更加有趣，”ING 经济学家詹姆斯·史密斯 (James Smith) 表示。 “这是一个非常接近的机会，但我们仍然想说央行明天将加息。”

;

;他表示，预期的加息可能是英国央行目前最后一次加息。

;

; p>;

;毕马威英国首席经济学家 Yael Selfin 表示，近期全球油价上涨以及食品价格的潜在压力将给英国央行带来压力。

;

;“这些不仅可能减缓通货紧缩进程”她说。

;

;上周，欧洲央行;将利率提高至历史新高;，但暗示利率可能会暂停。预计美联储将;维持利率不变周三持有;。

;

;单独的数据显示，英国央行还有进一步令人鼓舞的消息;薪酬交易;失去了更多的通胀热度。

;

;最新数据也让总理里希·苏纳克(Rishi Sunak)的政府松了一口气。他承诺在 2024 年大选之前将今年的通胀率降低一半。

;

;“今天的新闻表明，应对通胀的计划正在发挥作用 - 简单明了，”财政部长杰里米·亨特 (Jeremy Hunt) 表示。

;

;“但它仍然太高，这就是为什么坚持我们将其减半的计划更加重要，这样我们就可以减轻家庭和企业的压力。”

;

;他说英国可以无力继续“借贷狂欢”，这是对民意调查中民调高涨的反对党工党的猛烈抨击。

;

;随着工厂出厂价格下跌，有迹象表明未来通胀压力将进一步减弱截至 8 月的 12 个月内增长了 0.4%。制造商投入价格下降2.3%。

;;一幅壁画以已故锡克教领袖哈迪普·辛格·尼贾尔 (Hardeep Singh Nijjar) 的形象为特色，他于 6 月在古鲁纳纳克锡克教古德瓦拉 (Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara) 寺庙的场地上被杀2023 年，加拿大不列颠哥伦比亚省萨里，2023 年 9 月 18 日。路透社/Chris Helgren/资料照片;
;

;周三，印度敦促在加拿大的国民和计划前往加拿大的国民保持谨慎，因为在锡克教分离主义领导人被谋杀事件中，两国驱逐了对方的一名外交官，两国关系因此恶化。

;

;自总理贾斯汀·特鲁多周一表示 ;加拿大;正在调查有关印度政府特工可能参与的“可信指控” 6 月在不列颠哥伦比亚省哈迪普·辛格·尼贾尔 (Hardeep Singh Nijjar) 被谋杀。

;

;“鉴于加拿大的反印度活动日益增多以及政治上纵容的仇恨犯罪和犯罪暴力，那里的所有印度国民以及那些考虑旅行的人，印度外交部表示，敦促印度保持高度谨慎。

;

;总理纳伦德拉·莫迪政府彻底否认了加拿大关于新德里特工与谋杀案有联系的怀疑。

;

;“鉴于加拿大安全环境不断恶化，特别建议印度学生格外谨慎并保持警惕，”该部在一份声明中补充道。

;

;自 2018 年以来，印度一直是加拿大最大的国际学生来源国。

;

;加拿大国际教育局表示，这一数字去年增长了 47%，达到近 32 万人，约占海外学生总数的 40%。该局还帮助院校向国内学生提供补贴教育。

;

; p>;

;周三，私人娱乐公司 BookMyShow 宣布取消加拿大歌手 Shubhneet Singh 的印度巡演。

;

;加拿大官员迄今为止;拒绝透露;为什么他们认为印​​度可能与 Nijjar 的谋杀案有关。

;

;印度主要反对党国大党也支持政府拒绝这些指控，敦促采取立场反对对国家主权的威胁。

;

;“特鲁多为被宣布为恐怖分子的哈迪普·辛格·尼贾尔 (Hardeep Singh Nijjar) 辩护绝对是可耻的，这表明了当前的情况有多么严重。加拿大政权与卡里斯塔尼的同情者同床共枕，”国会资深议员阿布舍克·马努·辛格维 (Abhishek Manu Singhvi) 在社交媒体平台 X（以前称为 Twitter）上发帖称。

;

;;Khalistan; 是一个独立的锡克教国家的名称，其创建是印度血腥的锡克教叛乱的目标20世纪80年代和90年代印度北部旁遮普邦发生了数万人被杀的事件。

;

;作为当时的执政党，国大党领导了与分裂分子的斗争，并最终镇压了叛乱。

;

; >;

;但这夺走了国大党主要领导人的生命，总理英迪拉·甘地 (Indira Gandhi) 于 1984 年被锡克教保镖暗杀，旁遮普省首席部长比特·辛格 (Beant Singh) 于 1995 年在锡克教分裂分子的炸弹爆炸中丧生。;

;尽管印度境内的叛乱分子几乎没有任何支持，但澳大利亚、英国、加拿大和美国的一小群锡克教徒支持分裂主义要求，并偶尔在其大使馆外举行抗议活动。

;

;新德里对叛乱活动的死灰复燃保持警惕，长期以来对加拿大的锡克教分离主义活动感到不满，并敦促加拿大对反印度分子采取行动。

;

;印度对外间谍机构前负责人研究与分析部门表示，特鲁多在议会中宣布驱逐一名印度外交官，这很奇怪。

;

;《经济时报》援引 AS Dulat 的话说：“我们不会做这些事情。”印度报业托拉斯通讯社。 “我们不会四处暗杀，让我说得很清楚。”

;

;加拿大是印度旁遮普邦之外锡克教徒人口最多的国家，2021 年约有 77 万人将锡克教作为他们的宗教信仰人口普查。

;

;一些印度分析人士表示，渥太华不会阻止锡克教抗议者，因为他们是一个具有政治影响力的团体。

;

;“特鲁多似乎正在通过迎合极端主义边缘来参与有毒的国内政治。 《印度快报》在一篇社论中表示，敦促化解争端。

;

;双方均表示，他们正在冻结有关潜在贸易协议的冗长谈判。加拿大和印度一直在努力提高低水平的双向贸易，2022 年加拿大贸易总额为 1.13 万亿美元，而双边贸易额仅为 102 亿美元。

;

;（1 美元=1.3452 加元）

;;阿塞拜疆周三（9 月 20 日）袭击了由亚美尼亚人控制的分裂地区纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫，尽管俄罗斯和美国呼吁双方停止升级战争。;
;

;亚美尼亚周三，在巴库开始进攻以恢复对其领土的完全控制后 24 小时，阿塞拜疆分离的纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫地区的分离主义势力投降并同意停火。

;

;根据双方确认的协议，从周三下午 1 点（格林威治标准时间 0900）起，分离主义势力将解散并解除武装，并于周四开始就该地区的未来以及居住在那里的亚美尼亚人进行会谈。

;

; “阿尔扎赫共和国”表示，在巴库军队突破他们的防线并占领了一些战略要地而世界却无所作为之后，他们被迫同意由俄罗斯维和人员转达的阿塞拜疆的条件。

;

;“阿尔扎赫共和国当局接受俄罗斯维和特遣队指挥部的停火提议。

;

;阿塞拜疆确认已达成停火协议。

;

;这一结果似乎将为阿塞拜疆将约 12 万亚美尼亚人融入其社会铺平道路——一些亚美尼亚人表示他们担心这一前景——并完全控制自 1991 年以来一直处于两场战争中心的山区苏联解体。

;

;亚美尼亚表示，尽管阿塞拜疆声称自己在卡拉巴赫没有军事力量，但并未进行军事干预。它指责巴库试图对卡拉巴赫进行种族清洗，但阿塞拜疆对此予以否认。

;

;目前尚不清楚有多少亚美尼亚人会选择留在卡拉巴赫，也不清楚是否会有大量人逃往亚美尼亚。

;

; >;

;阿塞拜疆的军事行动导致数十人死亡、数百人受伤，遭到美国和一些欧洲国家的尖锐批评。

;

;他们表示卡拉巴赫问题本应通过谈判解决，巴库的这些行动使当地本已严峻的人道主义局势进一步恶化。

;

;阿塞拜疆周二在炮击支持下向卡拉巴赫派遣部队，试图用武力迫使该分裂地区就范，从而引发新战争的威胁其邻国亚美尼亚。

;

;阿塞拜疆在其所谓的一系列挑衅之后采取了行动，并且在巴库所说的来自山区的分离主义分子发动的袭击中杀死了一些部队之后，阿塞拜疆已封锁该地区九年月。

;由于相信美联储将维持利率不变，投资者更加关注周三发布的新预测将揭示美国央行政策制定者对经济“软着陆”前景的认可程度，以及随之而来的利率环境。

;

;短期内，预​​计美联储官员仍将预计另一种利率2023 年底前加息，可能会在 10 月 31 日至 11 月 31 日期间交付。 1 次会议。

;

;但除此之外，更新后的经济预测摘要的发布将迫使美联储政策制定者表明他们是否相信近期的一系列良好数据能够持续 - 通胀放缓且强于预期就业和经济增长 - 或者是否需要采取更严格的货币政策来对抗物价上涨，尽管存在着大流行后经济扩张硬性停止的风险。

;

;政策制定者的预测是德意志银行首席美国经济学家马修·卢泽蒂(Matthew Luzzetti)写道：“至少在2023年，可能会进行有意义的调整……包括上调增长和劳动力市场，以及下调通胀率。”他预计美联储官员的主体将仍预计今年将再次加息。

;

;如果出现这种情况，下一次加息确实可能是 2022 年 3 月开始的紧缩周期的最后一次，但对明年及以后的预测将表明持续多长时间预计高利率时期、通胀恢复目标的速度以及经济放缓和失业率上升的程度。

;

;新的预测和美联储最新政策声明即将发布美国东部时间下午 2 点（格林尼治标准时间 1800）。美联储主席杰罗姆·鲍威尔计划于半小时后召开新闻发布会。

;

;截至 6 月份发布的最后一组季度预测，美联储政策制定者的年终预测中值为经济增长 1.0 %，基本通胀率为 3.9%，基准隔夜利率将在 5.50%-5.75% 范围内，仅比 7 月份上次会议批准的范围高出四分之一个百分点。

;

; 6 月份的预测显示，明年经济增长预计将保持在 1% 左右，基本通胀率到 2024 年底将降至 2.6%，到 ​​2025 年底将降至 2.2%，距离美联储 2% 的目标非常遥远。 /p>;

;随着通胀放缓，利率也会下降。最后一组预测预计，美联储的政策利率将在 2024 年下降 1 个百分点，在 2025 年下降 1.2 个百分点，年底在 3.25%-3.50% 的范围内。

;

;这些幅度是多少价值观的转变，特别是围绕明年的降息设想，以及对 2026 年的长期前景的第一印象，将相当于对美联储是否相信软着陆（即通胀在不受影响的情况下下降）的信心进行默认投票。由于经济的弹性，重大失业或经济衰退变得更加强劲，或者由于担心价格压力可能持续并迫使政策立场更加收紧而变得更加疲软。

;

;数据 ;自美联储 7 月会议;以来，这可能支持任一论点，而最近发布的消息往往传递出混合的信息。例如，周一发布的一项住宅建筑商调查显示，9 月份的情绪有所恶化。周二的;商务部报告;显示 8 月份新屋开工下降 11.3% ，而作为未来投资领先指标的新增许可证则健康增长了 6.9%。最近的价格数据显示通胀加速，但由于能源成本高企等原因，通胀可能会消退，而且趋势通胀的步伐仍在放缓。

;

;但鲍威尔和其他美联储官员表示，为了让他们对广泛的“通货紧缩”充满信心，经济必须在一段时间内低于其潜力运行。

;

;到目前为止，这种情况还没有发生，经济在整个上半年都在增长。今年高于美联储官员认为经济非通胀趋势的 1.8% 利率，并持续到第三季度。

;

;这可能意味着未来预测中的经济增长，并且可能先锋基金全球首席经济学家兼该基金巨头投资策略小组负责人约瑟夫·戴维斯表示，货币政策也转向收紧。

;

;鉴于经济表现，美联储“可能需要加息”戴维斯表示，“进一步（或）需要在更长时间内收紧政策”，以减缓经济增长，并补充说“软着陆仍然是可能的，但不太可能。”

;

;The father of a woman who died in ;the Hawaii wildfires; last month has launched a novel lawsuit against three major landowners, seeking to hold them responsible even though they did not start the fire and the blaze ignited on land they do not own.

;

;Harold Wells of Arizona, whose 57-year-old daughter Rebecca Rans perished in the deadly Lahaina blaze, contends the property owners should pay damages because they allowed invasive species of towering grasses to grow wild on their property, accumulating dense fire fuel next to the historic town. Scientists have said the invasive grasses were likely the largest factor in ;spreading the fires;, more than warmer temperatures or hurricane weather.

;

;When wind-driven flames sparked by downed power lines reached the defendants' properties, the grass exploded into a conflagration that engulfed homes, businesses and escape routes, the lawsuit claims. At least ;97 people died; in the Aug. 8 fire.

;

;If successful, the case could provide a blueprint for holding property owners liable at a time when ;catastrophic fire risk; is growing due to climate change and more people ;living near wilderness areas;, legal experts said.

;

;Wells sued the governments of Hawaii and Maui County, along with Hawaii's largest private land holder, Kamehameha Schools, formerly known as the Bishop Estate, in state court in Wailuku.

;

;David Minkin, an attorney for Maui County, told Reuters that only a small portion, if any, of its land was involved in the blaze.卡美哈美哈学校发言人拒绝置评。 Officials in Hawaii's attorney general's office, which represents the state, did not respond to a request for comment.

;

;The Wells case appears to be the first to argue that maintaining huge volumes of dry vegetation in a fire-prone area is an “inherently dangerous activity,” akin to storing explosives.

;

;If Wells' attorneys can prove the grassy conditions near Lahaina met that legal standard, the landowners could be held “strictly liable,” meaning Wells would not have to prove the defendants were negligent or started the blaze.

;

;Wells is seeking unspecified damages, including punitive damages, related to funeral costs as well as pain and suffering. His attorneys on Tuesday filed a similar case on behalf of the children of Rans' partner, who also died in the blaze.

;

;The strict liability theory typically applies in cases involving highly risky operations like the storage of dynamite. Legal precedent holds that the storage operator may be held responsible for an explosion regardless of the cause.

;

;The combustible material in Lahaina included non-native species such as Guinea grass that was partly blamed for a 2018 blaze that destroyed more than 20 homes in the area. A resident described the event to a reporter for the Honolulu Star-Advertiser as "tornadoes of fire."

;

;The dense, seven foot (2.1 meters) grasses invaded abandoned sugar plantations near the town and produced up to 15 tons per acre of fire fuel, according to a study by a fire prevention organization.

;

;Jim Bickerton, who represents Wells, said the dried grass could meet the inherently dangerous standard in drought conditions and high winds when "the extreme level of risk posed is essentially becoming analogous to a dynamite situation."

;

;By their nature, novel legal strategies face daunting challenges. Wildfire victims have struggled over the years to hold landowners liable, even for fires ignited on their property.

;

;The US Forest Service was sued over the 2003 Cedar Fire in California, which started on its land and destroyed more than 2,000 homes and killed 15 people. A judge ;dismissed the case; in 2009 because, while the agency's land management led to a huge build-up of fire fuel, that was not the actual intent of its policies.

;

;Bickerton said even if the Hawaiian court determined the grasses are not inherently dangerous, he could still successfully sue the landowners on a theory of negligence, because the 2018 Maui blaze showed the hazards of not maintaining the grass.

;

;Rick Linkert, a California attorney who specializes in defending wildfire cases, said it may not be easy for Wells' legal team to show negligence. They would have to demonstrate there was an accepted standard for managing grasslands and that the landowners ignored it, he said.

;

;"If nobody is controlling vegetation in that way, in Maui or anywhere in the Hawaiian Islands, I just don't see how they establish that," Linkert said.

;

;Like dozens of other lawsuits that have been filed over the deadly blaze, Wells is also ;suing Hawaiian Electric; for the company's alleged failure to maintain its power lines, which Wells said were blown down in the high winds and ignited the Lahaina blaze.

;

;Hawaiian Electric;(HE.N); has said its downed wires apparently ;started one fire;, which it said local officials declared extinguished.该公司表示，在另一场灾难性火灾发生前六小时，公司关闭了电源。 Several government agencies are investigating the cause.

;

;Maui County has filed its own lawsuit against Hawaiian Electric, which it blames for the fire.

;

;The company said in a statement that its immediate focus is on rebuilding Maui.

;

;The insured losses from the disaster alone have been estimated at ;more than $3 billion;, which would exceed the shareholders' equity of Hawaiian Electric if it were found liable. That has encouraged victims to look for other potential defendants including landowners, lawyers for victims said.

;

;The private landowner, the Kamehameha Schools, has a $15 billion endowment, according to its website. It was established by Pauahi Paki, the last royal descendant of the Kamehameha line, to promote the wellbeing of people of Hawaiian descent.

;

;"An important factor when we're dealing with such large loss, there really may not be any one entity that can pay all of it," Bickerton said.

; Wed, 20 Sep 2023 18:25:04 +0800 Analysis: Fixing oversight culture may be biggest challenge in averting future bank criseshttps://reuters.com/article/usa-banks-regulators-analysis/analysis-fixing-oversight-culture-may-be-biggest-challenge-in-averting-future-bank-crises-idUSKBN30Q0QS
;;2023-09-20T10:11:52Z;
;

;As US regulators start to overhaul the way they police lenders after three banks failed this year, they will have to address examiners' hesitancy to raise red flags, a deep-seated problem that has plagued the system for years.

;

;The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) ;this month released its; review into the demise of First Republic Bank, the third official postmortem into the crisis which also felled Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and New York's Signature Bank.

;

;Each failed following depositor runs. The postmortems on why bank managers and regulators were not able to avert disaster reveal a common theme: Federal Reserve and FDIC examiners tasked with ensuring banks follow rules and remain sound spotted major problems but acted too slowly.

;

;Federal Reserve examiners spotted "foundational" issues with SVB's liquidity risk management in 2021 but were still drafting a disciplinary action the day it died, the Fed report found. Likewise, a 2019 FDIC notice warning Signature Bank's board about liquidity planning problems "remained outstanding" when it failed, according to the FDIC's review.

;

;The FDIC has blamed staffing challenges and examiners' lack of urgency. The Fed ;has cited; deregulatory zeal under former Republican President Donald Trump's administration and excessive efforts at consensus building, as well as examiner hesitancy, for delaying action. Both agencies ;have pledged to improve the speed and forcefulness of supervision;.

;

;However, five former bank examiners and regulatory officials told Reuters that cultural problems and structural obstacles have been embedded in the supervisory system for decades and are unlikely to be solved easily. Chiefly, examiners worry that confronting bank management with problems will spark blowback and that their bosses may not support them when that happens.

;

;"Once you've detected the information; do you have the courage to do something?" said Charles Calomiris, a professor at Columbia Business School and former official at the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC), noting examiners worry that raising red flags will "make everybody angry."

;

;The OCC, a third US bank regulator, did not respond to a request for comment.

;

;Signature Bank's management was "generally dismissive" of examiners' findings, ;the FDIC said;. First Republic's examiners could have done more to challenge management in 2021 but "would have likely encountered pushback" because growth was strong and interest rates were low at the time, the regulator also found.

;

;"It can be challenging to take action on banks that are seemingly healthy," said Michael Clements, a director at the Government Accountability Office (GAO), which has been calling for more timely and assertive action by bank supervisors for decades. "Managers will push back on examiners."

;

;The Fed declined to comment. An FDIC spokesman referred to Chair Martin Gruenberg's previous comments that the problems identified at Signature Bank are "an area of urgent focus."

;

;Examiners monitor banks and perform onsite supervision. They rate their health on a range of metrics and can instruct them to correct problems. But the work is with the rarest of exceptions strictly confidential. That means there is often little public accountability, even after something blows up.

;

;One former supervisor in the Fed system who spoke on the condition of anonymity said examiners need, more than anything, to feel that their superiors back them. Under former Fed Vice Chair for Supervision Randal Quarles, however, the committees overseeing supervisory work raised the threshold for evidence required to support examiners' concerns, the former supervisor said.

;

;According to the SVB report, staff said that under Quarles, a Trump appointee, they felt pressured to go easier on banks while meeting "a higher burden of proof for a supervisory conclusion."

;

;Quarles said that this is not true and that supervisors have "always been fully supported" by Fed leadership. "I expressly encouraged examiners to focus on liquidity risk and concentration of deposit risk," he said in an email to Reuters.

;

;Fed decision-making can be further slowed because lines of authority are decentralized and encourage excessive consensus-building, the former supervisor who spoke anonymously added, a point also supported by the SVB review. It found that the need for consensus between regional Fed banks and staff in Washington often slowed processes.

;

;"The problem with supervision at the Fed is that it is too obsessed with process and not enough with actual risk," said Quarles.

;

;Michael Barr, Quarles' successor, publicly said in June that it can be hard for examiners to confront bank management in good times, and that Fed culture makes it difficult to act quickly. ;In May testimony, he called for; a "culture that empowers supervisors to act in the face of uncertainty."

;

;But how to get there remains an open question. Barr has floated imposing additional capital requirements when supervisors detect weak risk controls, providing an incentive for banks to act quickly.

;

;Others say it may be more effective to take the problem of bearing bad news out of the hands of supervisors by setting automatic thresholds for enforcement action.

;

;The GAO, for example, has in the past suggested supervisory "trip wires" or "triggers" that would require banks to take "prompt corrective action" based on factors other than capital, such as asset quality or concentration.

;

;"If you get to that point, you simply take more forceful action, taking a little bit of discretion away," said Clements.

;The ratio of CEO pay to the average, non-supervisory production worker at the biggest US companies has jumped from less than 40 to 1 over the last four decades to nearly 400 to 1, the Economic Policy Institute calculated in 2022.

;

;In contrast, some workers for the Big Three automakers who were ;protesting on the Ohio to Michigan highway; this week said they needed to work two jobs to survive.

;

;;Restructuring the US economy; to make things more "fair" for workers and voters has been a long-stated goal of President Joe Biden's economic plan. Capitalism is supposed to work "for the good of the American people," Biden has said, but decades of "trickle down" tax cuts for companies and the wealthy in the US have undermined the system.

;

;As the strikes began last week, Biden echoed Fain, saying automakers should offer more of the share of their profits to workers. But the White House has ;little leverage; besides the bully pulpit and is studying how to stave off the economic impact of a long-term walkout instead.

;

;Attempts to address rising CEO pay in decades past have not had the intended effect, said Rosanna Landis Weaver, director of wage justice and CEO pay at As You Sow, a non-profit shareholder advocacy group.

;

;Salaries were held down, but compensating top executives through the use of stock options that many considered "free money" increased, she said.

;

;"Anytime you tried to squeeze pay in one area it popped out in another - the balloon was never squeezed enough to pop, just enough for the air to go somewhere else."

;More than a dozen European states, as well as Australia and Canada, on Wednesday asked the World Court to decide it has jurisdiction in a case brought by Kyiv alleging that Russia abused the Genocide Convention to provide a pretext for the invasion of Ukraine.

;

;Ukraine ;brought the case; to the International Court of Justice (ICJ), the highest UN court for disputes between states, days after Russia launched a full scale war on its smaller neighbour on Feb. 24 last year.

;

;Germany told judges the countries "strongly believe" the court has jurisdiction. German representative Wiebke Ruckert said her country had a strong interest in how the genocide treaty was interpreted "not least in view of our past".

;

;Kyiv argues that Russia is abusing the 1948 UN Genocide Convention, adopted in the aftermath of World War Two, by saying the invasion was justified to stop an alleged genocide in eastern Ukraine.

;

;Some 150 states have signed the Convention and as such have an interest in how it should be interpreted by the court. An unprecedented number of states have intervened in this ICJ case, in a strong show of support for Kyiv.

;

;Russia asked the court on Monday to ;throw out the case;, claiming Kyiv's legal arguments were "hopelessly flawed" and that Moscow had not actually invoked the genocide treaty when it used the term genocide.

;

;Some 32 states will address the court, all in support of Ukraine, which wants the court to go on and hear the case on merit and find that Russia must pay reparations.

;

;Ukraine says there was no risk of genocide in eastern Ukraine, where it had been fighting Russian-backed forces since 2014. The convention defines genocide as crimes committed "with intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group, as such".
